statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Colorado State 69, Utah 61 (OT)
article.story: SALT LAKE CITY (AP) -- Sean Morris was fighting the flu and a bone bruise on his shooting hand. Neither seemed to affect his shot much. Morris hit five 3-pointers, including one with 15 seconds left to force overtime and two more early in the OT to give Colorado State a 69-61 win over Utah on Wednesday night. "Any time in overtime, if you can get a couple of 3s or big buckets, that can really take the wind out of them," said Morris, who scored all 17 of his points in the second half and overtime. The Rams (13-11, 2-9) snapped a seven-game losing streak and won for just the second time in the Mountain West Conference this season -- with both victories coming over the Utes (12-11, 5-7). Jason Smith added 15 points and eight rebounds for the Rams, who were 24-for-47 from the floor and committed just five turnovers in the final 25 minutes. Colorado State also rallied from a six-point deficit late in regulation, then outscored Utah 14-6 in overtime. "We finally got some stops there. They were kind of ramming it down our throats," Colorado State coach Dale Layer said. "But it all culminated with Sean's big 3 there to put it into overtime and that gave us some momentum, and some juice to finish the job." Utah had four players score in double figures, but they were also the only Utes who scored. Johnnie Bryant and Luke Nevill both scored 18, Jonas Langvad added 15 points and Bryant Markson scored 10 for Utah. The Utes had won four of five and were making a late run in the conference standings. But the Rams, who were tied with TCU for the worst record in the league, swept Utah for the first time since 1994. "I'll take the blame," coach Ray Giacoletti said. "We were not ready to play and when you're not ready to go, something can turn and bite you." The Utes went on a 10-0 run late in regulation to take a 51-45 lead, but couldn't hold off the Rams at the end. Nevill, who also had nine rebounds, converted a three-point play with 29 seconds remaining, when his layup rolled around the rim several times before dropping through then made his free throw to put Utah ahead 55-52. But Colorado State, which had just tied the game at 52-all on a 3-pointer by Stephan Gilling, got it to Morris for a 3-pointer and another tie. "We did everything right. We switched every screen and he just hit a tough shot," Giacoletti said. Bryant missed a long shot at the buzzer and the game went into overtime. Morris opened the overtime with a 3-pointer from the top of the key, then stepped back a few feet for his next 3, which gave Colorado State a 61-55 lead with 3:43 left. Markson answered with a 3-pointer, but that was as close as Utah got. Morris' older brother, Micheal, beat the Utes on a 3-pointer three years ago in Colorado State's last road win in the MWC -- March 6, 2003. The older Morris scored two points Wednesday, but Sean's big night carried the family and the Rams. "His 3 to put it into overtime and his back-to-back 3s to start overtime was the difference between winning and losing," Layer said. The Rams shot as well from 3-point range (8-for-14) as they did from the free throw line (13-for-21), making 67 percent from both. Utah was off from everywhere, making just 19 of 49 field goal attempts. "They did a great job of taking us out of our offense. They forced turnovers and had us scouted really good," Langvad said.
